author: albusdompeldorius
content: Exactly! It sacrifices some generality, but doesn't sacrifice any of the security of zk-rollups, so it is still secure even if no-one is watching the chain, unlike plasma or optimistic rollups!

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Now, if we can generalize it to work in a hybrid kind of way with contracts, it would be even more interesting. That's what I'm mostly thinking about right now.

author: albusdompeldorius
content: My current line of thinking is that changes to some common state (eg. Uniswap token pool balances) would need to be in calldata, but that would be quite small and amortised over all users who change it in a block.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think there is significant value in a zkRollup that can "only" do ERC20 and ETH transfers (throwing in ERC-721 transfers as well would be nice).

author: sky.cactus
content: There is a dire need for an Ethereum payment network for people selling real-world goods and services for crypto that doesn't require huge transaction fees.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, if you could get a handful of exchanges onto such a zkRollup along with maybe a payment processor or two then all of those people can move off of L1 for their transfers.

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Yeah. Adding support for ERC-20 and ERC-721 should be possible, you would mainly have to replace the map Address -> Value with a map Address -> (Token -> Value), and make the necessary adjustments that follows from this change.

author: .vbuterin

author: .vbuterin
content: They've been a very effective transfers-only rollup with really low fees (because they actually bother to do compression) for a long time now

author: randomishwalk
content:
I would lob in a problem that is parallel to the one that <@301186049323958275> called out (or orthogonal?) ‚Äî who is effectively solving the fiat/crypto on and off ramps today in a way that is regulatory compliant, cheap, fast and with a great UI/UX? It‚Äôs certainly not Coinbase or the other cex‚Äôs out there. People are trying like Square, Wyre, and Moonpay but no one has cracked the most critical problem with crypto to-date

This to me is the only product decision that is stopping crypto from reaching 1B users and beyond‚Äîit‚Äôs just far too difficult for the average regular person to use. 

<@273808422753796097> have you given any thought to this issue? I‚Äôm certain you have haha so would love to hear what you (and other folks here) think!

author: .vbuterin
content: That's more a regulatory problem than a technical one, no?

author: randomishwalk
content:
I‚Äôm not sure, I guess that‚Äôs the question. At what point does the technical community need to meet the real world half-way and engage with regulators & normal users who are not crypto nerds like all of us here üòÇ

If indeed the goal is to decentralize the internet and empower more people, regardless of border, race, political affiliation, economic access etc, to be a meaningful participant in the value creating opportunities that Web 3 will certainly bring ‚Äî then we must all see that technology and engineering here need to be reinforced by PR, marketing, lobbying the right political decision makers and meeting users where they are, rather than dragging them into the rabbit hole with us

The easier question to me is more of a product design question. The question I am asking myself is ‚Äúwho is building the global bridge between the old physical world and the new, shinier, decentralized digital world?‚Äù 

Unless we all think our entire lives will be spent on the internet, this is one of the highest order problems to solve and transcends any individual L1 community

Again just my two cents but I welcome discussion around these points! Appreciate when others challenge my viewpoints üòá

author: randomishwalk
content: What worries me is the emergence of a new kind of tribalism. ETH vs BTC or ETH vs SOL seems much more minor than ‚Äúcrypto vs the world‚Äù

content:

author: sky.cactus
content: Ideally, a user who buys some ETH on Coinbase, uses it to buy some stuff via Bitpay, and then withdraws via Binance would never hit L1 (or at least, would hit L1 with the minimum data possible, which is 6-bytese with the solution proposed by <@848181786763984926> above).

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Actually, my solution would be very efficient for the use case where many users withdraws from a CEX. Since there is one sender (the CEX) and many recipients, all transfers would be batched together, so there would only be 6 bytes of calldata for each batch of transfers.
